newsitem.title: USA: Moody's raises Illinois GO bonds to Aa3 from A1.
newsitem.headline: Moody's raises Illinois GO bonds to Aa3 from A1.

text.p: Moody's Investors Service Monday raised Illinois' general obligation bond rating to Aa3 from A1.
The move affects about $5 billion of outstanding debt.
The rating agency also said it upgraded the rating on $1.6 billion of Build Illinois revenue bonds to Aa3 from A1.
Robert Kurtter, a Moody's analyst, attributed the upgrades to improvement in the state's financial condition and its elimination of most of a nagging backlog of Medicaid bills.

He also pointed out the state's undesignated general fund deficit, as measured on a Generally Accepted Accounting Principles basis, improved to $1.1 billion at the end of fiscal 1996 from more than $2 billion in fiscal 1993.
The rating upgrades came as the state was preparing to competitively sell $250 million of GO bonds Thursday. The upgrades followed three downgrades of the state by Moody's between 1991 and 1995.
